moves.1. d4: This was a fun game with a nice forced checkmate at the end.  Black fought well and only really made one big mistake...
moves.3. e3: I used E3 this time instead of E4.  I give up control of d5 and f5 and block my dark bishop in exchange for the strenght of protecting d4.
moves.3... Nf6 4. Bxc4: Quickly white has nice postion and development.
moves.5... Bb4+: check threat.  I don't mind the impending exhange as it move my bpawn closer to the centre and supports the d4 square.  Since I am castleing kingside, its all good.
moves.6. Nc3 Bxc3+ 7. bxc3: The predicated exhange is done.  Black can now castle and beat white to it!
moves.9. a4: I try this attempt to open up the double pin with Ba3
moves.9... a6: Here is the big mistake.  I believe black may not have realized the threat.
moves.11... Qxf8: In exchange for the bishop.  Black is still in the game but never recovers..
moves.12... b6 13. Qc2: freeing up the second rook and putting some pressure on h7
moves.13... Nc6: black is developing the last of his power players
moves.16. Ng5: Even more pressure on h7.  3 attackers and 2 defenders...
moves.16... Qe8: Avoids an attack on the Q with the knight and potential mate
moves.18... Bxa4: look familiar???  Good move but I have a few options.
moves.19... Bxd1 20. Bxa8 Bb3 21. Be4: even steven but white still has position and up those 2 points from the earlier rook/bishop exchange
moves.21... Nxe4 22. Qxe4: I questioned black's willingness for this exchange as it put white in a potential mating postion.  It seeems usual to exchange players so willingly when black was behind.
moves.22... g6 23. Qe5+ Kg8 24. Qxc7: Captures pawn and puts the Q in a position of power on the 7 rank
moves.24... Bc4 25. Rxb6: white is very strong here as Rb8 threatens to capture the black Queen
moves.25... Kg7 26. Rb8: This is a forced checkmate from this postion unless the black Q captures the attacking white rook.  Can you spot the mate if Qa4?
moves.26... Qa4: I know the game is won at this point.  Its 3 move to mate.
